meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Friday 2026-02-13: this is a no-snow/zero-precip day with a cold start and some early mist. Temperatures are in the upper teens around bus time, warming steadily into the 40s by afternoon. Morning wind chills bottom out around ~10°F (6 AM) — nowhere near Michigan cold-closure thresholds (≤ -20°F). Roads should be dry with no new snow/ice, and winds are light-to-moderate (peaking ~12–13 mph). The only minor operational issue is reduced visibility from mist around/after sunrise (notably ~8 AM with ~1 mile visibility), but that’s typically manageable with normal caution. Net: very high confidence schools run normally; snow-day probability effectively near zero.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, dry high-pressure (1024–1026 mb) dominating overnight with clear skies; no precip signal. This is a classic ‘quiet winter day’ setup in West Michigan where districts virtually never close for snow/ice because none is occurring.

Clear/calm overnight followed by shallow morning mist (visibility ~1 mile around 8 AM) with temps in the teens (°F) and light wind. Historically this produces normal school operations; at most it creates minor localized slow-downs, not district-wide closures.

Diurnal warm-up above freezing (low–mid 40s °F) after a cold morning. In February this more often *reduces* risk by improving road conditions (melting/evaporation) unless there is pre-existing slush/refreeze from prior storms—which is not indicated by your forecast data.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Mid-February in Rockford (north of Grand Rapids) is climatologically deep-winter, so schools and road crews are fully ‘in stride.’ On a day with **0" forecast snow and 0" precip**, Rockford-area districts almost always run normally. The main non-snow hazard you occasionally watch for this time of year is a surprise glazing event (freezing drizzle) or dense fog—neither is showing up in this forecast.
unusual_factors: Morning mist indicated around 8–9 AM with visibility near ~1 mile at 8 AM (then improving).
Big temperature swing: teens in the morning to low/mid 40s in the afternoon—this can cause *refreeze* risk only if roads are wet/slushy from previous precipitation (not shown here).

local_microclimates: Low-lying areas and river/creek corridors (including near the Rogue River) can hold mist/fog a bit longer around sunrise.
Rural edges of the district and shaded backroads/bridges can stay icy *if* there’s residual moisture; bridges freeze first even on otherwise dry days.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan districts (including Rockford) are well-equipped for snow removal and typically do not close without measurable snow/ice or dangerous wind/drifting.
With no falling precip and light winds (max ~12.5 mph), there’s no drifting/blowing snow mechanism in play.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor elevation/terrain differences can influence fog and isolated slick spots, but not enough to drive a district-wide closure under a dry forecast.

history.confidence_assessment: **High confidence**: Your provided forecast shows **no snow, no precipitation, and light winds** for Friday 2026-02-13. The only operational nuisance is **brief morning mist** (around 8 AM), which historically is far more likely to produce ‘use caution’ messaging than a closure. A reasonable Michigan-calibrated estimate for a full snow day under these conditions is **~1–3%** (mostly capturing rare last-minute surprises like an unforecast thin glaze or a localized fog-related pileup concern).

safety_recommendations: Overall pattern is a quiet weather day (no precip/snow) with temperatures warming above freezing by late morning/early afternoon; anticipate normal MDOT/county road performance and generally bare pavement on main routes.

Main watch-out is early-morning slick spots: temps ~17–20°F overnight with high humidity and **mist around 8–9 AM** (visibility down to ~1 mile at 8 AM). Any leftover moisture from prior days (shaded intersections, bridge decks/overpasses, low-lying areas) could support patches of black ice.

Have transportation staff and first bus drivers do a quick ‘canary’ check of known cold spots (bridges on major corridors, shaded curves, rural gravel segments) between ~5:45–6:30 AM; if they report glazing, spot-salt those locations rather than district-wide changes.
Remind parents/staff: allow extra following distance for the first hour after sunrise; use low beams in mist and watch for pedestrians at crossings where visibility is reduced.

Prioritize clearing/salting: bus loop areas, building entrances, and parent drop-off zones—refreeze is unlikely after mid-morning with temps climbing into the 30s/40s, but early-morning packed snow/ice in lots can still be slick.
No extreme cold trigger: wind chills are generally around +10 to +15°F near the bus pickup window—cold but not in the -20°F automatic-closure range.

Snow-day implication (Michigan-calibrated): this is an ‘open’ day. In most states, the morning mist + cold might raise more concern; in Michigan, with no active precip and warming temps, this typically stays operational unless there’s unexpected pre-existing ice.

Expect MDOT trunklines and Kent County primaries to remain in good shape; any issues would be localized black ice rather than snowpack. Snow-day probability from roads alone is very low unless there is an unexpected overnight freeze/flash-ice event or dense fog creating safety visibility issues.

That combination is typically not an outage-producing setup. Consumers Energy’s statewide outage count appears very low (319 affected, ~99.98% with power), which implies normal grid operations and low risk of power-driven school closure. The main operational risk Friday is cold start/comfort (teens around daybreak with wind chills near ~10–12°F), but that’s manageable with normal building heat if power is available.

No credible web source retrieved in this run showed wind chill/feels-like ≤ -20°F for Rockford, MI on the Fri 2026-02-13 morning window. The provided API hourly values bottom out around ~10°F feels-like at 6 AM.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: WeatherAPI forecast for Fri 2026-02-13 in Rockford, MI shows a cold but not extreme morning: temps ~17–19°F with feels-like ~10–11°F around 6–8 AM, no snow, and modest winds (generally 4–6 mph early, increasing later). Web verification was partially successful: timeanddate pages show current/near-term feels-like values in the teens, broadly consistent with ‘cold but not dangerous’ conditions, but they are not clearly pinned to the Feb 13 morning hourly forecast. Weather.com results available via web retrieval were inconsistent and appear stale/misaligned with the requested date (some reflect early-February conditions). I was not able to reliably fetch Rockford’s official NWS point forecast page or AccuWeather’s Feb 13 RealFeel forecast from the returned sources in this run. Based on what was retrievable, there is no evidence that the -20°F wind chill closure trigger is met for Fri Feb 13, 2026; however, because the most authoritative web sources (NWS/AccuWeather) were not successfully captured here, you should treat the web cross-check as incomplete rather than a strong confirmation.

final.decision_rationale:
All expert inputs largely agree this is a quiet winter day meteorologically: no accumulating snow, light-to-moderate winds, and wind chills around +10°F during bus hours—nowhere near the ≤ -20°F automatic-closure threshold. The main weather nuisance is shallow morning mist/fog around 8–9 AM with visibility near ~1 mile, plus a plausible but localized black-ice risk on bridges/overpasses and shaded backroads if residual moisture exists. In Michigan (and specifically West Michigan), that combination almost never produces a district-wide weather closure; it’s typically handled via spot-salting and cautious driving. The only meaningful ‘conflict’ is the safety assessment labeling ice formation risk as “moderate” despite zero precip; reconciled as: ice risk is not district-wide, but localized/spotty where untreated moisture lingers. 

Separately, local news intelligence indicates Rockford Public Schools are already scheduled CLOSED for Mid-Winter Break on Fri Feb 13, 2026—so the practical outcome is “no school,” but that is calendar-driven, not a weather ‘snow day.’ My probability above is for a weather-driven snow day/closure decision (if the district were otherwise operating).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Most likely: Open/normal operations (weather) with minor caution messaging for mist and bridges
alternative_scenarios.impact: Buses run; advise slower speeds, low beams in mist, watch for isolated slick spots.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Localized freezing fog/black-ice reports on rural routes trigger a 2-hour delay (weather-driven)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Delay to allow spot-salting and daylight; limited disruption.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Rare surprise glaze/dense fog + multiple incidents leads to full closure (weather-driven)
alternative_scenarios.impact: District-wide closure despite low-precip forecast; would require conditions worse than currently indicated.

for_schools: Recommendation (weather): OPEN with monitoring; consider targeted messaging about mist/visibility and bridge slick spots.
Have first drivers/transportation staff perform an early ‘canary’ route/bridge check 05:45–06:30; spot-salt known cold spots if needed.
If visibility <0.5 mile is observed broadly or multiple bus routes report glazing, be ready to pivot to a 2-hour delay by ~06:15.
for_residents: Expect a cold start and patchy mist around 8–9 AM; use low beams and allow extra stopping distance.
Watch for black ice on bridges/overpasses and shaded neighborhood streets early; conditions should improve mid-morning.
for_authorities: If crews are available, prioritize spot-salting bridges/overpasses and shaded curves before ~06:30.
Monitor for any fog-related crash clusters around 07:30–09:00; use dynamic messaging if available.

positions.rationale: Purely meteorologically, this looks like an “open” day: no snow, no rain, light-to-moderate winds, and wind chills not remotely close to cold-closure criteria. The only plausible weather-related disruption would be localized slick spots from overnight radiational cooling plus shallow morning mist, but with zero modeled precip and a strong warm-up, that risk is typically patchy and manageable with spot salting. So I keep a small non-zero probability (rare unforecast micro-icing/dense fog pockets or an overnight incident) but it’s very low.
keyFactors: No active winter precip: forecast total precip 0 mm and total snow 0 cm for Fri 2026-02-13 (all hours show 0 precip/0 snow).

Temps: cold early (near 17–21°F around typical bus window) but warming above freezing by late morning; not an extreme-cold closure setup. Lowest modeled wind chills are ~10–12°F around 6–8 AM—well above typical wind-chill closure thresholds used in MI (often nearer ≤ -20°F).
Wind: modest (max ~12–13 mph; gusts mostly <20 mph). No blowing/drifting snow mechanism.

Visibility: patchy mist around 8–9 AM with vis down to ~1 mile at ~8 AM, improving thereafter. This is usually a “slow down” hazard, not a district-wide closure trigger absent dense fog (<1/4 mi) or icing.
Synoptic signal: high pressure / dry day implied by steady high pressure (~1018–1026 mb) and clear/sunny conditions—low forecast volatility for surprise snow bands.

positions.rationale: From a historical-closure perspective, the provided pattern (high pressure, dry air mass, no snowfall, modest winds) corresponds to an overwhelmingly “normal operations” day in West Michigan. The only historically relevant hazard in the data is shallow morning mist with subfreezing temps, which can produce isolated slick spots if residual moisture exists—but that scenario rarely drives a district-wide closure by itself in this region. Therefore the weather-driven snow-day probability is very low (≈1–3% range); I’m placing it at 1.5% to account for rare surprises (unforecast patchy glaze/freezing fog impacts, or an unusual incident-based decision). Separately, if the decision question is simply “Will school be closed?”, then the probability is ~100% due to the scheduled Mid-Winter Break noted by the NEWS agent.
keyFactors: Forecast shows **0 precip / 0 snow** all day Friday (2026-02-13) with light winds—historically, Rockford-area districts almost never declare weather closures without active accumulation, icing, or extreme cold.
Temps are cold at bus time (upper teens) but **not** in the historical wind-chill closure regime (no signal near ≤ -20°F).
Only notable operational nuisance is **brief morning mist** around ~8–9 AM with visibility near ~1 mile, which historically leads to caution/slowdowns rather than district-wide closure.
Mid-February operations context: crews, drivers, and families in West Michigan are typically fully winter-adapted; this raises the threshold for closing on marginal hazards.

Non-weather override: NEWS agent indicates **Rockford Public Schools are scheduled closed for Mid-Winter Break on Feb 13, 2026**—so a “snow day” (weather-driven closure) is effectively moot even if conditions were marginal.

positions.rationale: From a NEWS/district-operations standpoint, the dominant driver is calendar status: Rockford Public Schools list Feb 13, 2026 as closed for Mid Winter Break, and nearby districts show similar scheduled closures. That means the practical probability that students experience a “snow day” (weather-triggered closure) is effectively near zero because the district is not planning to operate regardless of weather. Even if we interpret the question strictly as “probability schools would close due to weather if they were scheduled to be open,” the meteorology/safety inputs show no snow/ice event and only minor mist, which rarely triggers a full closure in West Michigan. I therefore hold a ~1% probability to capture only edge cases (e.g., an unforecast freezing-fog/flash-glaze issue or major overnight incident prompting a safety closure announcement) rather than anything suggested by the forecast.
keyFactors: Rockford Public Schools are already scheduled closed for Mid Winter Break on Friday, Feb 13, 2026 (i.e., a non-weather closure is already in place).
Forecast is benign for operations: 0 precip / 0 snow, light-moderate winds (max ~12.5 mph), temps rising into the 40s by afternoon.
Only notable morning issue is mist around ~8–9 AM with visibility briefly near ~1 mile—typically handled with caution messaging, not closures.
No supporting community/incident signals provided (no outage spike, no road-closure/crash reports, no cancellation buzz).

debates.topic: You rate ice formation risk as “moderate.” With forecast precip at 0 and no freezing drizzle signal, I’d frame the *meteorological* ice risk as low-to-possibly-localized (bridges/shaded spots only). If you have evidence of wet roads/snowmelt from prior day(s), call it out explicitly—otherwise ‘moderate’ may overstate district-wide risk.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 14.0% spread. Average probability: 5%.
